title: Government risks being the first since 1924 to lose Commons vote on a Queen’s Speech
text:
Boris Johnson faces a battle to avoid becoming the first prime minister since 1924 to lose a vote on a Queen’s Speech.

The Conservative leader is currently operating without a majority in the Commons, with just 288 MPs taking the party whip – 32 short of the number needed to ensure victory.

Yet, if the 10 DUP MPs and 22 of the 23 Independents who were formerly Conservatives join with the Government, the Prime Minister could avoid a defeat.

Traditionally, the failure to get a Queen’s Speech through Parliament is a sign the Government no longer commands the support of the Commons, and a change of administration is needed. That convention has now been superseded by the 2011 Fixed Term Parliaments...
description: Boris Johnson faces a battle to avoid becoming the first prime minister since 1924 to lose a vote on a Queen’s Speech.
